title: Test Your Understanding: JavaScript Data Types
description: How well do you understand primitives vs objects?

questions.question: Which of the following are primitive types in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: String, Number, Boolean, and Symbol are primitives. Object and Array are reference types.

questions.question: Primitives are passed by value in JavaScript.
questions.explanation: True! Primitives are passed by value, meaning each variable gets its own copy.

questions.question: Objects are passed by reference in JavaScript.
questions.explanation: True! Objects are passed by reference, meaning variables store a pointer to the same object in memory.

questions.question: What does typeof null return?
questions.explanation: typeof null returns 'object' - this is a well-known bug in JavaScript that can't be fixed for backward compatibility.

questions.question: What happens when you do: let a = 5; let b = a; b = 10; console.log(a);
questions.explanation: Prints 5. Since primitives are passed by value, changing b doesn't affect a.

questions.question: What happens when you do: let obj1 = {name: 'John'}; let obj2 = obj1; obj2.name = 'Jane'; console.log(obj1.name);
questions.explanation: Prints 'Jane'. Since objects are passed by reference, both obj1 and obj2 point to the same object.
